legal.charges: *18:371 Conspiracy to willfully make a bomb threat; *18:844(e) Willfully making a bomb threat; *26.5861(d) Possession of a non-registered destructive device

narrative: In October 1997, in Tulsa, Oklahoma, white supremacist James Viefhaus, Jr., 28, was charged with conspiracy to willfully make bomb threat, willfully making a bomb threat, and possession of a non-registered destructive device. This was carried out through Viefhaus leaving a phone message threatening to bomb 15 U.S. cities via an Aryan Intelligence Network hotline operated by Viefhaus and his fiancé at the time, Carol E. Howe, both the founding and only members of the National Socialist Alliance of Oklahoma. Viefhaus was motivated by his right-wing beliefs as evidenced by his organization which sought for "the destruction of blacks, Jews, homosexuals, and federal law enforcement agents". Howe acted as an informant for the case and charged against her were dropped.
source: court documents, local news articles

legal.charges: 18:842 Possessing and manufacturing explosive devices

narrative: In 1997, in Orlando Florida, Todd Vanbiber, age 29, was charged with possessing and manufacturing explosive devices. Vanbiber, an alleged member of the neo-Nazi National Alliance and the League of the Silent Soldier, had been plotting to set off pipe bombs on major roadways in Florida to distract from a bank robbery he was planning but accidently set off the bombs early in his storage shed when checking them. His actions were motivated by his neo-Nazi ideology.
source: News articles, Databases

legal.charges: threatened use of a weapon of mass destruction

narrative: In 1999 in Elkgrove, CA, Kiles, 49, and Patterson, 42 were charged with 4 felony weapons charges. The men - members of the San Joaquin County Militia - had amassed a stache of guns, ammunition, bomb chemicals and methamphetamine ingredients with the goal to blow up storage tanks near Elk Grove that together hold about 24 million gallons of liquid. The men hoped to prompt a declaration of martial law, then civic unrest and, ultimately, a militia takeover of the federal government, court documents say.
source: FBI 1999, FBI History, news document

legal.charges: 18:2384.f Seditious Conspiracy; 18:2332aa.f Use of Certain Weapons of Mass Destruction; 18:842p.f Teaching or Demonstrating Making of Explosive Devices; 18:924c.f Violent Crime/drugs/machine Gun [4 Counts]; *26:5841f Registration of Firearms

narrative: Defendants charged in the 'STONE' group were members of the group Hutaree. According to the indictment, Hutaree members view local, state, and federal law enforcement as the “brotherhood”, their enemy, and have been preparing to engage them in armed conflict. The indictment also alleges that the Hutaree planned to kill an unidentified member of local law enforcement and then attack the law enforcement officers who would gather in Michigan for the funeral. According to the plan, the Hutaree would attack law enforcement vehicles during the funeral procession with improvised explosive devices with explosively formed projectiles, which, according to the indictment, constitute weapons of mass destruction. Subsequently, and in furtherance of this plan, David Brian Stone, the Hutaree’s leader, obtained information about such devices over the Internet and e-mailed diagrams of such devices to a person he believed capable of manufacturing the devices. Additionally all nine defndants were charged with carrying or possessing a firearm during a crime of violence on at least one occasion. All of the defendants pleaded not guilty and were aquitted with the exception of David Brian Stone Sr., Joshua John Clough, and Joshua Matthew Stone who pleaded not guilty and were found guilty on some charges and sentenced to time served of 28 months.
source: Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Charging Documents

legal.charges: 18:922(g)(1) and 924(a)(2) Possession of a Firearm by a Convicted Felon; 26:5861(d) and 5871 Possession of Unrefistered Destructive Devices [3 counts]; *18:922(g)(1) Felon in possession of a firearm

narrative: In 2013, agents with the FBI arrested militia member Buford Braden “Bucky” Rogers, of Montevideo, Minnesota, after discovering two Molotov cocktails, two “black powder and nail devices,” a pipe bomb, and a semi‐automatic rifle at his home. Rogers was a convicted felon prohibited from possessing firearms. An FBI affidavit asserted that Rogers regularly talked of plans to use his militia group, a tiny group called the Black Snake Militia, to cut off communications to the City of Montevideo, raid the National Guard Armory, and bomb the Montevideo Police Department. Rogers pleaded guilty to being a felon in possession of a firearm and possessing an unregistered destructive device and received a 40‐ month prison sentence.
source: Court Documents, Charging Documents, Databases, News Articles

narrative: Woodring, an anti-government extremist, commits three sabotage attacks over several weeks on the local power grid. One attack on a high-voltage station in Scott, Arkansas, causes $4 million in damage. He pleads guilty to using fire to commit a felony, among other charges.
source: court documents, arkansas times

legal.charges: 18:371f Conspiracy to Defraud the United States; 18:2332aa.f Use of Certain Weapons of Mass Destruction

narrative: Terry Eugene Peace, Brian Edward Cannon and Cory Robert Williamson, attempted to obtain thermite and pipe bombs in order to launch terrorist attacks against the federal government. Based on online comments they made, the trio seem to have hoped to spark a government overreaction that would cause the militia movement to rise up. Cannon, Peace and Williamson targeted the infrastructure supporting their federal agency targets because they believed this would reduce the amount of unnecessary casualties and make it difficult for the government to respond to their attack. When going to pick up the pipe bombs the men were intercepted by police due to work with an informant. All defendants pleaded guilty and were sentenced to 144 months in prison.
source: Court Documents, Local News Articles, Governmental Reports and Release, Charging Documents

narrative: On March 30, 2016, in Tyngsborough/Tyngsboro, Massachusetts, 61 year old Danny M. Kelly started a fire, placed incendiary devices on utility lines, and left a manifesto railing against government corruption near the scene. Prior to the attack, Kelly had a history of civil and criminal disputes with local government, including an eminent domain case regarding the use of his property for a public utilities project.
source: Charging document; Governmental reports and release; News articles

legal.charges: 18:1366(a), Destruction of an Energy Facility; 18:922(g)(l), Possession of a Firearm/Ammunition by a Restricted Person; 21:844(a), Possession of a Controlled Substance;

narrative: On September 25, 2016, Stephen Plato McRae fired shots at the Buckskin Electrical Substation, causing the substation to overheat and fail. In the plea agreement for this charge, McRae admitted to damaging several other facilities and authorities agreed not to charge him for those offenses. The locations of the other damages are: Libson Valley Substation in San Juan County on April 1, 2015; Quinn River Substation in Humboldt County, Nevada on August 31, 2016; and Baker Substation in White Pine County, Nevada, on September 14, 2016. According to the state, he told a confidential informant he was trying to "destroy industrial capitalism" and "do millions of dollars of damage to the fossil fuel industry.”
source: Charging documens; Government reports and releases; Local news articles

legal.charges: two counts of first-degree murder, two counts of aggravated assault with intent to commit a felony and three counts of armed kidnapping

narrative: Arthurs, a former neo Nazi (Atomwaffen), is accused of murdering his two roommates because they disrespected Islam, his new religion. Devon Arthurs shot 22-year-old Jeremy Himmelman and 18-year-old Andrew Oneschuk, his roommates in a Tampa, Florida apartment, before giving himself up in a nearby smoke shop. Authorities investigated his third roommate after find a framed photo of Timothy McVeigh in the apartment and enough explosive materials for a bomb
source: News Articles

legal.charges: Possesion of unregistered explosive device, unlawful storage of explosive material

narrative: (Army National Guard) Brandon Russell is a dangerous Neo-Nazi leader who was found to have lethal bomb-making materials in his Florida apartment after his roommate shot two of their other roommates. Russell is a dual citizen with the US and the Bahamas and an active duty member of the Florida National Guard. Russell and his roommate Devon Arthurs (the shooter) were co-founders of the Atomwaffen Division. Russell was not found to be connected to the murder of his roommates. The bomb-making materials were found amongst other neo-Nazi propaganda, including a framed picture of Timothy McVeigh and the Turner Diaries. Russell's attorney argues that Russell has mental deficiencies (ADHD and Autism) and that the bomb-makng materials were not going to be used. One of Russell's murdered roommates, Andrew Oneschuk, was also a member of AWD and had ties to the Azov Battalion in Ukraine.
source: NBC, Court Documents

legal.charges: making false statements and disobeying a regulation

narrative: (marine) Lance Cpl. Vasillios G. Pistolis, a Marine alleged to have connections to a violent neo-Nazi organization, was booted from the Corps on July 11, according to Maj. Brian Block, a Marine spokesman. In June, Pistolis was sentenced before a military court to 28 days confinement, reduction in rank to E-1 and forfeiture of two-thirds pay for one month following an explosive report exposing the Marine’s connection to the neo-Nazi group Atomwaffen Division and his violent participation at the “Unite the Right” rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, in August 2017.

legal.charges: 18.2-32 Murder [2 counts]

narrative: On December 22, 2017, in Reston, VA, Nicholas Giampa, 17, was charged with two counts of murder. This was carried out by Giampa sneaking into his girlfriends home, when her parents discovered him, he drew a handgun and shot both parents before unsuccessfully attempting suicide by shooting himself. As @doctorpepper35, Giampa tweeted about his hatred of transgender people and his admiration for Adolf Hitler. He tweeted about using Jews as target practice. Online, Giampa had repeatedly interacted with white supremacist groups, in particular the Atomwaffen Division. The Frickers had staged an intervention for their daughter to keep her from dating an "outspoken neo-Nazi" and had even reported Giampa's hate speech to the special education high school the two attended. Initially, Giampa was ruled incompetent to stand trial due to brain damage from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. After spending months in a mental hospital, Giampa was deemed competent to stand trial. Giampa's sentencing is coded as data not available because his records are not available through Fairfax County Circuit Court, and his name has not appeared in the news since 2019.
source: News Articles, Local News Nrticles

legal.charges: 18:371 Conspiracy to commit an offense against the United States; 18:2101(2)(a) Using interstate or foreign commerce to organize or participate in a riot

narrative: On May 3, 2019, Benjamin Drake Daley, 26, pleaded guilty in Charlottesville to one count of conspiracy to riot in connection with the August 2017 “Unite the Right '' rally in Virginia and other political rallies in California, alongside Benjamin Drake Daley. They were both members of the white supremacist organization, Rise Above Movement (RAM). Daley has been identified as one of the founders of RAM, and was chiefly responsible for organizing their presence at Unite the Right. They admitted to intentionally provoking and engaging in violent confrontations; RAM even held combat training meetings prior to the rallies.
source: Governmental reports and release; Court documents; News articles

Court records show that he posted $30,000 bond June 12. An arraignment and plea are scheduled for Tuesday...The complaint alleges that Hung was stockpiling weapons. A photo that authorities said they obtained from his iCloud account that was included in the documents shows assault rifles, semi-automatic pistols, magazines, ammunition, a tactical vest, binoculars, a rifle scope and other equipment. The agents say the guns were likely purchased out of state and kept at the home in San Marino...Hung was charged with illegally acquiring the Glock found in his truck and buying three out-of-state guns that he brought to California. Defendants Morrison and Muscio are co-founders of the Wolverine Watchmen, a right-wing militia group associated with the boogaloo movement. These eight defendants were not accused of directly participating in the kidnapping plot but rather providing material support for Adam Fox's plan to kidnap the governor. Adam Fox aimed to kidnap the democratic government and trigger a civil war before the 2020 election leading to societal collapse. Bellar, Morrison, and Musico pleaded not guilty and were each sentenced to a maximum of 20 years in prison. Molitor and both Null brothers pleaded not guilty and were acquitted.

These eight defendants were not accused of directly participating in the kidnapping plot but rather providing material support for Adam Fox's plan to kidnap the governor. Adam Fox aimed to kidnap the democratic government and trigger a civil war before the 2020 election leading to societal collapse. Bellar, Morrison, and Musico pleaded not guilty and were each sentenced to a maximum of 20 years in prison. Molitor and both Null brothers pleaded not guilty and were acquitted.
source: Charging Documents, Governmental reports and releases, News articles, Local news articles

legal.charges: 18:922(g)(4) Any person who has been "adjudicated as a mental defective" or "committed to a mental institution" is prohibited under Federal law from shipping, transporting, receiving, or possessing any firearm or ammunition

narrative: "A federal criminal complaint filed...[which] charges 21–year-old Cameron Emerson Casey Rankin with one count of being a prohibited person in possession of a firearm as a result of previously being committed to a mental institution. FBI agents arrested Rankin...and recovered a black semi-automatic rifle during the execution of a search warrant at his residence...According to the criminal complaint, Rankin was in unlawful possession of a firearm, with the capability and means to affect violence in furtherance of his beliefs and has expressed a desire to overthrow the government, specifically, the “three letter agencies” such as ATF, FBI and IRS...Rankin attempted to purchase two long guns from a San Antonio retail outlet on March 23, 2018, but was denied the firearms transactions under the “Prohibited Category” for previously being committed to a mental institution. After being warned by agents with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) that he was a prohibited person, Rankin posted pictures of himself with a firearm on social media. On May 30, 2020, Rankin and others, carrying long guns and pistols, appeared at the Alamo in downtown San Antonio to attend a protest in reaction to the death of George Floyd. The next day, Rankin posted on his Facebook account photos of himself and others carrying a firearm at the protest as well as comments about his disdain for police including, “…hope they burn the precinct down” and “I’m BOOGALOO we hate police.”...on August 4, 2020, Rankin posted a “selfie” photo on his Facebook timeline showing him holding a black, semi-automatic rifle in a vertical position against his shoulder with his finger on the trigger. Rankin posted other photos which included a quote, stating, “Diligently Plotting to Take Over the World in order to Leave You Alone”. On August 11, 2020, Rankin arrived at the airport in Manchester, New Hampshire. He flew out of San Antonio International Airport the previous day. Rankin checked a semiautomatic handgun in his luggage while at the ticket counter, but missed a connecting flight in Philadelphia, PA. Upon his arrival in Manchester, Rankin was met inside the terminal by ATF agents who served Rankin written notice that he is prohibited from possessing firearms. The agents also provided him with copies of his mental health records. Agents seized the handgun and ammunition from inside Rankin’s luggage. Rankin threw the notice letter and mental health records in the trash receptacle before leaving the airport terminal. (DOJ press release)"
source: DOJ OPA release, Court Documents, News

narrative: "On April 7, 2022, Ivan Harrison Hunter, a 28-year-old resident of Boerne, Texas, was sentenced in the District of Minnesota to 52 months incarceration after pleading guilty to one count of rioting. Hunter, an adherent of the Boogaloo movement, traveled from Texas to Minnesota in May 2020 and met up with other Boogaloo movement members who had mobilized to Minneapolis following the murder of George Floyd. On May 28, 2020, during a period of rioting near the Third Precinct Building of the Minneapolis Police Department, Hunter fired 13 rounds from an AK-47 assault rifle into the entryway of the building. Following this criminal conduct, Hunter returned to Texas and continued to communicate with his fellow Boogaloo movement members, including Steven Carrillo – who shot two Protective Services officers at the Ronald V. Dellums Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse in Oakland, California on the same day as Hunter’s actions in Minneapolis." (George Washington University, Program on Extremism)

legal.charges: 18:1201(c) kidnapping, kidnapping conspiracy

narrative: On December 16, 2020, Adam Fox, Barry Croft Jr., Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were indicted following a plot to kidnap the governor of Michigan. The men trained together and then planned to kidnap Governor Whitmer before the November 2020 Election. According to the SS Indictment, defendants Adam Fox and Barry Croft Jr. were affiliated with the “Three Percenter” movement (sometimes rendered III%), while defendants Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were members of the Wolverine Watchmen, a Michigan-based “militia” group with similar anti-government views. Ty Garbin entered a guilty plea in January 2020 to the original indictment charging him with conspiracy to kidnap Governor Whitmer and was sentenced to 75 months in prison. In April 2021, a Superseeding Indictment was issued to the five remaining defendants. Harris and Caserta pleaded not guilty and were both acquitted of all charges. Franks pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 48 months in prison. Fox and Croft Jr. pleaded not guilty and were convicted by jury trial in August 2022 of conspiracy to kidnap the governor and conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction against persons or property. Croft was additionally convicted of knowingly possessing an unregistered destructive device, specifically an improvised explosive wrapped in pennies for shrapnel. Fox was sentenced to 192 months in prison, and Croft was sentenced to 235 months in prison.
source: Charging documents, Local news articles, News Articles, Court documents, Governmental reports and release

narrative: Subleski was charged in a criminal complaint with a violation of 18 United States Code, Section 2101, for using a facility of interstate commerce to incite a riot and committing an act of violence in furtherance of a riot. The complaint against Subleski alleges that he was a member of the militia known as the United Pharaoh's Guard (UPG) who define themselves as Boogaloo Bois. “Boogaloo” is a term referencing a violent uprising or impending civil war. The complaint further alleges that on January 6, 2021, contemporaneous with the Capitol riots, Subleski incited a riot in downtown Louisville, Kentucky, through the use of social media and other electronic communications, and while inciting individuals to riot, he communicated through social media that it was “Time to storm LMPD.” On his Facebook page, Subleski wrote that "once R.O.E. (Rules of Engagement) get lifted ISSA BE A WATERFALL of tyrant and patriot (B)lood alike."

On December 25th, 2020, Turner, while participating in a protest caravan driving through St. Matthews, confronted St. Matthews Police Officers following a traffic stop of the caravan and that during the confrontation Turner was openly carrying an AR-pistol and an additional hand gun. Following the arrest, Turner made a number of Twitter and Facebook posts threatening police officers.

legal.charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building

narrative:
Christian Alexander Secor, 22 of California, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and was sentenced to 42 months of incarceration. On January 6, Secor entered the Capitol through the Senate doors, entered House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office, and sat in Vice President Mike Pence's chair on the Senate Floor. He was also charged with assaulting police officers within the Capitol, but this charge and others were later dropped. He made  prior comments about civil war and wrote on his Twitter account that "We're legit in the Turner Diaries timeline." He was a UCLA student at the time of the riot and wore a red Make America Great Again hat and carried an America First flag. 

"The FBI said Secor is a self-identified Groyper, a network of "alt right figures who are vocal supporters of white supremacist and 'America First' podcaster Nick Fuentes. The FBI stated a tipster reported Secor founded the campus organization "America First Bruins" and is a member of Bruins Republicans. The FBI stated Secor can be seen in a group of rioters pushing their way into the building. Court documents state a tipster told the FBI that Secor moved back in with his mother after the riot, got rid of his phone and car and bragged that he would not be caught for his involvement." (USA Today)
source: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

legal.charges: 18:922a(6) False Statement During Purchase of Firearm; 18:922(o) Illegal Possession of a Machine Gun; 18:2&922(o) Illegal Possession of a Machine Gun, aiding and abetting

narrative: On October 2, 2019, FBI attempted to arrest Eric Allport in Madison Heights, Michigan. Allport was shot and killed after opening fire and wounding one FBI agent. Danny Jo Thompson ll was arrested later that day for supplying Allport with a machine gun that was in Allports vehicle at the time of his arrest. Allport was killed before he reached his vehicle. Thompson and Allport were members of the Bogoloo movement and shared strong anti-police attitudes. Text messages proved that Thompson was aware that Allport was a convicted felon and knew that Allport was planning to use the acquired machine gun to kill law enforcement.
source: Court Documents, Press Release

Lijbers often communicated and coordinated with the Bugaloo Bois, and found that Lijbers encouraged other members to engage in political rallies and violence inlcuding the Capital protests.

narrative: Andrew Ryan Bennett, a Columbia, Maryland Proud Boy, "livestreamed from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. In the four videos Bennett broadcast to Facebook, he wears a baseball hat adorned with the “Proud Boys” motto. In one of the videos, Bennett says, “ if you can hear me, share my stream in Discord for me,” seemingly referring to the messaging platform that’s been used by the alt-right. At one point, he chanted “break it down!” with a crowd—referring to a door located in the Speaker’s Lobby that was barricaded by police. Air Force veteran Ashli Babbitt, one of the four pro-Trump protesters who died on Jan. 6, was fatally shot by a police officer while attempting to break into the Speaker’s Lobby...Bennett shared conspiracy theories online prior to the insurrection. On Jan. 4, Bennett posted a conspiracy-laden message, including his belief that President Joe Biden stole the election and Hunter Biden’s laptop....On Jan. 11, Bennett admitted to federal agents that he went to D.C. and “that he knew it was wrong” to storm the Capitol. (Daily Beast)"
source: Charging Documents

The incident took place during a weekend of paramilitary training in Silver Creek, GA. On April 4, 2021, all five but Trimmell were indicted in Georgia for animal cruelty and livestock theft (Trimmell was only charged for aggravated cruelty to animals). Mathews, Lemley, and Bilbrough's cases were transferred via nolle prosequi to the federal courts.

Spazz, Spaz, Spazzo, Spazzolini; Case ID: 06062022_DP_4PROUDBOYS6), but Pezzola was removed from the case. Pezzola was named 3/7/22 in superseding indictment in new case, replacing 1:21-cr-52, and named again in a supersceding indictment 6/6/2022, having been added to the 4PROUDBOYS group case.)

legal.charges: 18:1201(c) kidnapping, kidnapping conspiracy; 18:2332a(a)(2)(a), (a)(2)(c), 18:921(a)(4) use of certain weapons of mass destruction, conspiracy to use a weapon of mass destruction; *18:1201(c) kidnapping, kidnapping conspiracy

narrative: On December 16, 2020, Adam Fox, Barry Croft Jr., Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were indicted following a plot to kidnap the governor of Michigan. The men trained together and then planned to kidnap Governor Whitmer before the November 2020 Election. According to the SS Indictment, defendants Adam Fox and Barry Croft Jr. were affiliated with the “Three Percenter” movement (sometimes rendered III%), while defendants Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were members of the Wolverine Watchmen, a Michigan-based “militia” group with similar anti-government views. Ty Garbin entered a guilty plea in January 2020 to the original indictment charging him with conspiracy to kidnap Governor Whitmer and was sentenced to 75 months in prison. In April 2021, a Superseeding Indictment was issued to the five remaining defendants. Harris and Caserta pleaded not guilty and were both acquitted of all charges. Franks pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 48 months in prison. Fox and Croft Jr. pleaded not guilty and were convicted by jury trial in August 2022 of conspiracy to kidnap the governor and conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction against persons or property. Croft was additionally convicted of knowingly possessing an unregistered destructive device, specifically an improvised explosive wrapped in pennies for shrapnel. legal.charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Offical Proceedings; *18:1512(c)(1) Destruction of Records in Official Proceedings; *18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Official Proceedings

narrative: Jessie Alexander Rush, the founder, "commanding officer," and "major" of the "1st Detachment, 1st California Grizzly Scouts" militia group, was alleged to have purposefully impeded the federal investigation and trial of Steven Carrillo, a Grizzly Scouts member who murdered a federal Protective Service Officer (PSO) in Oakland, California. Rush and his codefendants were charged with Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Official Proceedings for conspiring to destroy communication records relating to the murder. The Facebook group’s description stated, “they say the west won’t boog,” a reference to the “boogaloo” movement. The indictment alleged that a member of the Grizzly Scouts exchanged messages on the WhatsApp group with other Grizzly Scouts, in which that member allegedly told the group that he was preparing to engage in a shoot-out with law enforcement. Rush immediately instructed the Grizzly Scout member on the WhatsApp group to delete evidence on his phone. Rush, Blancas, Ybarra and Miksch then deleted records of their Whatsapp group, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement and Carrillo’s message to the group—“Dudes i offed a fed” indicating that he had killed a federal law enforcement officer. The indictment also alleges that less than an hour after the shooting in Ben Lomond, Blancas deleted files related to the Grizzly Scouts from a Dropbox account. Further, within hours of the shooting, members of the Grizzly Scouts, including Rush, Blancas, Ybarra, and Miksch allegedly began to reconnect on an alternative communications application. Moreover, the indictment alleges that the four defendants each deleted records of the WhatsApp group communications from their phones, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement. Rush pleaded guilty to Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Official Proceedings and was sentenced to 6 months in prison.
source: Charging documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release

legal.charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Offical Proceedings; 18:1512(c)(1) Destruction of Records in Official Proceedings; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Official Proceedings

narrative: Robert Jesus Blancas, the "1st Lieutenant" of the "1st Detachment, 1st California Grizzly Scouts" militia group, was alleged to have purposefully impeded the federal investigation and trial of Steven Carrillo, a Grizzly Scouts member who murdered a federal Protective Service Officer (PSO) in Oakland, California. The Grizzly Scouts are a militia group associated with the "boogaloo" movement. The indictment alleged that a member of the Grizzly Scouts exchanged messages on the WhatsApp group with other Grizzly Scouts, in which that member allegedly told the group that he was preparing to engage in a shoot-out with law enforcement. When a member admitted to killing a federal officer, Blancas deleted 20 files from their Dropbox account, including that discussing the group's rank structure, a non-disclosure agreement requiring members of the Grizzly Scouts to maintain the confidentiality of the group’s materials, a liability release waiver, descriptions of Grizzly Scouts uniforms, and a scorecard to assess members of the Grizzly Scouts with respect to combat, firearms, medical, and other training. Rush, Blancas, Ybarra and Miksch then deleted records of their Whatsapp group, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement and Carrillo’s message to the group—“Dudes i offed a fed” indicating that he had killed a federal law enforcement officer. The members then reconnected on alternative messaging servers where members repeatedly confirmed that they had destroyed evidence relating to the Grizzly Scouts, of which Carrillo was a member. Blancas was charged with Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Offical Proceedings, Destruction of Records in Official Proceedings, and Obstruction of Official Proceedings. Blancas pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 126 months in prison.
source: Charging documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release

narrative: "Sean David Watson showed a coworker videos on his cellphone that he claimed to have taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents indicate. That coworker then called the FBI to turn him in. In an initial interview with the FBI, Watson said he had participated in the Jan. 6 rally but denied being inside the Capitol building. In a second interview with agents, the FBI seized Watson's cellphone, and he admitted that he had entered the building. On that seized phone, law enforcement found photos from inside and outside the building and texts sent shortly after the riot, one of which read "I was one of the people that helped storm the capitol building and smash out the windows . We made history today. Proudest day of my life!” According to local news reports, Watson’s home is covered with messages, including “COVID1984," “Democrats stole the election" and "Veterans for Trump." NPR was not able to confirm his military history." (NPR)
source: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Local News Articles

legal.charges: 18:371 - Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;

narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Mark Grods coordinated with members of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Oath Keepers to interfere with the certification of the Electoral College vote on Jan. 6. Ahead of the Capitol riot, court documents state, Grods joined a group chat named on the encrypted messaging app Signal called "DC OP: Jan 6 21." Grods "brought firearms to Washington, D.C., and eventually provided them to another individual to store in a Virginia hotel," while Grods stayed with other members of the group at the Mayflower Hotel in D.C., prosecutors say. While the Capitol riot was ongoing, Grods allegedly rode in a golf cart with others members of the Oath Keepers to the Capitol, then breached the building while carrying what prosecutors describe as a "large stick." Soon after, Grods exited the building as law enforcement used pepper balls to try to force people out of the Capitol, the court documents state. Later, he allegedly met with other members of the Oath Keepers outside the Capitol building, and, in the days after the riot, said he had deleted his messages on Signal. As part of a plea agreement, Grods has agreed to testify in court and sit for interviews with investigators." (NPR)
source: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release

legal.charges: 18:371 conspiracy to manufacture firearms and ship them interstate; 18:922(a) (3) and 2 interstate transportation of firearms without a license; 26:5841, 5861(j), and 5871 and 2 interstate transportation of a firearm not registered as required;

narrative: Paul James Kryscuk, 35, Liam Collins, 21, Jordan Duncan, 26, Justin Wade Hermanson, 21, and Joseph Maurino, 22, conspired to manufacture, transport, and sell hard to obtain firearms and firearm parts in a manner that would hide these purchases from the federal government. Collins and Kryscuk were members of and made multiple posts on the “Iron March” forum, a gathering point for young neo-Nazis to organize and recruit for extremist organizations, until the forum was closed in late 2017. Collins and Duncan are former Marines assigned previously to Camp Lejeune in Jacksonville, NC. The defendants are also charged with conspiracy to damage the property of an energy facility in the US.
source: Charging documnets, Governmental reports and release

narrative: Kevin A. Tuck, 51, has been charged with Obstruction of an official proceeding, aiding and abetting, Entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, Disorderly and disruptive conduct in a restricted building or grounds, Entering and remaining in the gallery of Congress, Disorderly conduct in a Capitol building, and Parading, demonstrating or picketing in a Capitol building following his participation in the Capitol riots on 6 January 2021. Do you remember what conservative means, Republicans? Hear me out: We are embracing the homosexual lifestyle as if this is normal.” Tuck has pleaded non guilty to all charges, and is currently released on personal recognizance.

narrative: "Jackson, whose social media pages say he's a 100% disabled Marine, surrendered to the FBI on May 18: The FBI stated in court documents that he posted photos on social media of himself on Jan. 6 in a plaid shirt and other clothing he wore to the riot, photos agents later used to identify him. He was dubbed #TartanPlaidPB by online sleuths who are researching those who participated in the Capitol riot, then turning that information over to the FBI. Jackson is seen in photos numerous times on Jan. 6 with Proud Boys from Arizona, and wore one of their orange arm bands, the FBI stated. However, in an interview with the FBI at his home, agents said Jackson told them he is not affiliated with the Proud Boys and doesn't support their ideology. He said they gave him the orange band and he stayed with them for protection because he had traveled to Washington, D.C. alone. However, the FBI noted that in December, one of his social media connections tagged him in a post about a group of Proud Boys being in New York City. In a social media post included in the court records, Jackson said he didn't agree with the "MAGA tribalism," and didn't commit any violence. Jackson stated in the post that he had evidence of BLM, Antifa, police officers and "Non Trump" extremists "causing the mayhem." Jackson also stated that he's a college student studying to be a political science professor. "My only love is the United States of America," he wrote. At the Capitol, records show he carried a U.S. flag and was with a crowd singing The Star-Spangled Banner after the detonation of an explosive device in the crowd. He then pointed toward the Senate Wing of the Capitol and moved that direction. The agents noted he was seen on video in Statuary Hall and other locations inside the Capitol." (USA Today)
source: Charging Documents, Court Documents

narrative: Daniel Lyons "Milkshake" Scott, 28 of Florida, pled guilty to obstruction of justice/Congress and assault on a federal officer with physical contact and intent to commit another felony for his role in the January 6 Capitol raid. He was sentenced to 60 months of incarceration. He self-identifies as a Proud Boy member and wore a black ballistic vest, goggles, and a carabiner on his vest into the Capitol. He "has a tattoo of the organization on his left arm, according to the FBI. In a Wall Street Journal video from Jan. 6, Scott is seen walking alongside known members of the Proud Boys in Washington, D.C. On the same video, a man is heard screaming: “Let’s take the f***ing Capitol.” Another individual then answers: “Let’s not f***ing yell that, all right?” Ethan Nordean, one of the most powerful leaders in the organization, then responds: “It was Milkshake, man, you know … idiot.” Later at the Capitol, additional footage from various sources shows Scott pushing two police officers backward up the steps. Scott appears to be one of the first people to initiate contact with law enforcement and is seen later pulling officers into the crowd." (NPR)

narrative: "On March 24, 2022, Nathan A. Bergstrom, a 42-year-old resident of Arizona, was sentenced in the Western District of Kentucky to time served after pleading guilty to unlawful possession of a firearm. According to court records, Bergstrom is a “self proclaimed Boogaloo Boi” who was initially arrested at a Greyhound Bus Station in Phoenix, Arizona in January 2021. Bergstrom’s initial arrest was based on probable cause that he committed felony misconduct involving weapons, in violation of Arizona criminal code. After being released, Bergstrom failed to appear for his preliminary hearing, and a bench warrant was subsequently issued for his arrest. On March 13, 2021, Bergstrom was identified by the FBI as a participant in an event in Louisville, Kentucky, which was attended by multiple adherents of the Boogaloo movement. During the event, Bergstrom was arrested by law enforcement, who discovered a handgun on his person. A search warrant for Bergstrom’s cell phone also revealed screen shots of a pair of Greyhound bus tickets from New Mexico to Ohio, purchased under aliases, in an attempt to conceal Bergstrom’s identity and flee Arizona to avoid prosecution."
source: Charging Documents, Court Documents, Databases

narrative: "David Dempsey came to the attention of federal investigators through public tips from the Sedition Hunters -- people researching the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. On the day of the Capitol riot, federal prosecutors allege, Dempsey wore an American flag-themed neck gaiter as well as a combat-style helmet, camouflage pants and a tactical vest. In one video described in court documents, Dempsey stood in front of a gallows erected outside the Capitol and said that Democrats in Congress "need to hang from these motherf****** [pointing to gallows]," and that "Hopefully one day soon we really have someone hanging from one of these motherf******." During the riot, Dempsey allegedly used a lacrimal agent -- such as pepper spray -- as well as a crutch and a metal pole to attack police officers guarding the Capitol building. Dempsey was arrested in Santa Monica, Calif., in 2019 over allegedly using bear spray to attack anti-Trump protesters there. Dempsey pleaded no contest to a charge stemming from that incident. The Justice Department notes in its court filings that Dempsey can be seen in multiple photos from Jan. 6 wearing a black- and yellow-colored bracelet. Black and yellow are the colors associated with the far-right extremist group known as the Proud Boys. In one photo described in court documents, Dempsey made the OK sign while standing next to people wearing Proud Boys attire. The "OK" sign, which the Proud Boys frequently use, is often associated with supporters of white supremacy, according to the Anti-Defamation League. Dempsey was arrested on Aug. 26." (NPR)
source: Charging Documents

narrative: Joshua Dillion Haynes, 39 of Virginia, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Destruction of Property in the Territorial Jurisdiction. He was sentenced to 32 months in prison for his role in the Capitol Raid. He was recorded on video attacking members of the media at a staging area near the Capitol, crushing their equipment and stealing their camera. According to local news reporting, Haynes was angry specifically at CNN. "Court documents also show images taken from another video that allegedly show Haynes, along with two others, attempting to pull an air conditioning unit from outside the Capitol building. Haynes was identified by a tipster who used publicly available facial recognition software to match images from photos with a post from a Parler profile, and agents subsequently pulled the subscriber records to find a phone number and email address. Search warrant records for the phone reportedly show that Haynes used it the day of the riot to take pictures inside the Capitol and at the media staging area, and to text with friends. One selfie depicted Haynes inside the office of a U.S. senator, court documents indicate. Later, texts were allegedly exchanged between Haynes and other individuals that indicated he had broken windows and crawled into the Capitol. Prosecutors say one friend texted Haynes the message “dont [sic] be like antifa tearing stuff up.” Haynes replied, “ahhhh tooooo late,” “broke lotsa stuff,” and then “lol.” Haynes reportedly indicated he was seen destroying media equipment, saying "i Kicked the fake news a**" and "I am in the video destroying stuff but I'm wearing a mask." FBI agents went to Haynes' house and interviewed him at length. Haynes allegedly said he believed riot suspects were being treated badly in contrast to people who had participated in Black Lives Matter protests and that he respected those who used force against law enforcement to "stop the election from being stolen." Haynes attended a Proud Boys meeting in late 2020, court documents indicate, but denied he was a member of the far-right extremist group, saying he "would have joined the chapter, but it was too far away and there were no members of the Proud Boys in his local area."" (NPR)
source: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News Article

narrative: Steven Thurlow, 50 of Michigan, pled guilty to Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building for his role in the Capitol Raid."A witness contacted the FBI identifying Steven Thurlow as having been inside the Capitol building on Jan. 6, according to court documents. "The witness also provided screenshots of Thurlow’s Facebook posts, including one in which he is seen wearing camouflage tactical gear with a “Boogaloo” patch on his chest. The extremist Boogaloo movement anticipates a second civil war in America, and some adherents even seek to bring about that conflict. “Ahh nothing like a new pair of 511’s and fresh set of level IV SAPI’s in the plate carrier to go “peacefully protest” with, the caption to the picture read, referring to a high-level ballistic body armor plate, Thurlow had allegedly purchased. According to the FBI, Thurlow served in the Army from 1988 until 1991. A second witness told the FBI that Thurlow had become something of a “conspiracy theorist” after joining the military. Inside the Capitol building, photos show Thurlow lying on what appears to be a conference room table. He is also seen walking around the hallways recording on his cellphone, wearing a camouflage jacket, a yellow scarf and white rimmed sunglasses.""(NPR) He served in the US Army 101st Airborne 1988-1991, served abroad in Saudia Arabia for 6 months in 1990.

narrative: In the days leading up to January 6, 2021, Edward Thomas Spain, Jr, 55, posted messages on right-wing media site Parler warning that civil war was imminent and that Joe Biden's electoral college victory was a sign of America being a "banana republic." Then, on January 6, Spain  was found to have illegally entered the U.S. Capitol building with the mob in Washington D.C. He took photos of himself at the event and posted them to social media; the posts were then found by the FBI, who connected the posts to a phone number belonging to Spain and to usage of a cell site servicing the interior of the U.S. Capitol Building on the day in question. Spain was later interviewed at his Oklahoma home, where he confirmed his presence at the riot and his entrance into the United States Capitol. Spain was then charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot.

narrative: Footage of the livestream filmed within the U.S. Capitol on January 6 by Anthime Gionet showed Daniel Goodwyn, 32, who was called out as "sfthoughtcriminal," within the building during the violent events that took place that day. Goodwyn stated his full, correct name into the camera and was shown confronting officers that told him to leave by calling them "oathbreakers." An associate of Goodwyn conversed with him over Instagram regarding his participation in the riot and recorded a post to Goodwyn's account stating that he entered the Capitol without causing any damage; screenshots of both, turned over to the FBI, were what alerted them to Goodwyn in the first place. Goodwyn is a member of the politically-violent extremist group known as the Proud Boys, which was known to be prevalent and active in the siege of the U.S. Capitol on January 6th. In the months leading up to it, Goodwyn made several declarations over social media that signaled his affiliation with them as well as his support for the objections to the results of the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election that catalyzed the gathering of protesters at the U.S. Capitol that day. After this information was collected, Goodwyn was arrested and charged.

Homer added a camouflage helmet and googles to her tactical vest before entering the Capitol, where subpoenaed phone records indicate she remained for over an hour. Homer has posted a Proud Boys emblem to her social media, as well as photos taken at the Proud Boys’ Million MAGA March in Washington, D.C., in November 2020, according to the statement of facts. narrative: Federal prosecutors allege that Ronald Loehrke took part in the U.S. Capitol riot along with another man from the Seattle area named James Haffner. According to documents filed in federal court, Loehrke communicated in December 2020 with Ethan Nordean, a leader of the extremist group the Proud Boys who is facing conspiracy charges connected to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. Nordean allegedly told Loehrke that he wanted Loehrke "on the front line" with him on Jan. 6, 2021. Loehrke allegedly agreed and said he was bringing three "Bad mother f******" with him to Washington, D.C. On the day of the attack, prosecutors say, Loehrke and Haffner marched with members and associates of the Proud Boys toward the Capitol. They then allegedly dismantled barriers protecting the outside of the Capitol building. When a line of police protecting the outside of the Capitol stopped people from advancing farther, Loehrke allegedly said, "Don't back down, patriots! The whole f****** world is watching. Stand the f*** up today!" At one point, Haffner allegedly used an aerosol spray against an officer with the U.S. Capitol Police guarding an outer door. Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Ronald Loehrke was arrested in Cumming, Ga., on Dec. 3, 2021. (NPR)
source: Charging Documents

narrative: On March 23rd, 2021, Jonathanpeter Klein and his brother Matthew Leland Klein, both self-proclaimed members of the Proud Boys, were indicted on charges of 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Both pleaded not guilty to the charges, and their sentencing is pending. The Kleins came to the attention of law enforcement in fall 2020 when they attended Proud Boys rallies in Oregon. According to court records, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen at rallies in body armor and carrying a paintbull gun, and was photographed shooting the paintball gun at "an unknown target." On Jan. 6, federal prosecutors allege, Matthew and Jonathanpeter Klein joined with the mob and other members of the Proud Boys to breach the Capitol. Once inside, prosecutors said, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen engaging in a "celebratory exchange" with another Proud Boys member and displayed a Proud Boys hand signal. After the initial breach, the men allegedly exited the building and then "joined together to wrench open a secure door on the Capitol’s north side," allowing more rioters to enter the building "as part of a second or third wave of attacks."
source: Charging Documents, Local News, Governmental Reports and Release

narrative: "Prosecutors allege that at least two people called the FBI to report that Timothy Earl O'Malley had been at the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol and that one of those tipsters said O'Malley has previously identified himself as a Proud Boy. In an interview with the FBI, O'Malley said that he drove to Washington, D.C., from Florida to attend the pro-Trump rally. According to court documents, O'Malley wore a red softball batting helmet with a "Trump is my president" bumper sticker on the side, because he said he had heard that antifa followers had sacks of rocks they were planning to throw. In his interview, O'Malley described the scene at the Capitol as "mayhem" and admitted to entering the building, where he can allegedly also be seen on security camera footage. The FBI also obtained videos from O'Malley's cellphone through a warrant. In one video, O'Malley allegedly yells, "WE FOUGHT OUR WAY, ALL THE WAY IN THERE. AND WE FOUGHT OUR WAY BACK OUT ... WE SWARMED THE CAPITOL, THOUGH. HOT DAMN."" (NPR)
source: Charging Documents, Court Documents

narrative: Court documents indicate that Freedom Vy was identified as a person involved in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after law enforcement obtained and searched the phone records of Zachary Rehl, who is also charged and is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Vy is charged with Brian Healion and Isaiah Giddings, who were all allegedly part of a Telegram message with Rehl and one other unidentified person who was not in Washington, D.C., on Jan. 6, 2021. The group members coordinated their travel from Philadelphia to D.C., including sharing contact information and blood types, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on Jan. 5, 2021, according to court records. On the morning of Jan. 6, 2021, Vy and Healion took a selfie together at the Washington Monument. They both flashed the "OK" hand sign, which is associated with the Proud Boys, according to court documents. The four men then allegedly entered the west side of the Capitol, near the Senate, and appear there in photos and videos. (NPR)
source: Charging Documents

narrative: Law enforcement allegedly identified Isaiah Giddings as a person who participated in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot after searching the phone records of another person charged, Zachary Rehl, who is the president of the Philadelphia chapter of the Proud Boys, a far-right group. Giddings is charged with two other men, Brian Healion and Freedom Vy, who were allegedly part of a Telegram message group with Rehl and another person who was not in Washington, D.C., on the day of the insurrection. The group coordinated travel from Philadelphia to D.C. ahead of Jan. 6, 2021, and Giddings, Healion and Vy stayed together at The Darcy hotel in D.C. on the night before the riot, according to court records. On the day of the riot, Giddings allegedly appeared in a photograph outside the U.S. Capitol with Rehl and others, all flashing the "OK" hand symbol, a gesture associated with the Proud Boys. The four men then allegedly entered the Capitol building, where the four of them appear in several photos and videos. In a reply to a text the next day asking how they were doing, Giddings allegedly wrote: “Yes we have everything and everyone all accounted for ... none of our Philly guys had any PB gear the entire event just plain trump supporters from beginning to end." According to news reports, the Proud Boys were directed not to wear their signature black and yellow on the day of the riot, aiming to blend in with other Trump supporters. (NPR)
source: Charging Documents

narrative: In January 2022, Daniel James Anderson (26) of Kennewick, Washington, and Connor Duane Goodman of Auburn, Washington, were indicted on criminal charges after allegedly conspiring to build explosives to be used against law enforcement personnel. The charges include conspiracy to make or possess an unregistered destructive device and possession of an unregistered destructive device, as well as allegations of forfeiture. Goodman and Kennewick are members of a self-described anti-authority group known as the Verified Bois. The Verified Bois reportedly share the same beliefs associated with the “boogaloo” movement. Anderson was arrested and taken into custody in December 2021. It is not known if or when Goodman was arrested. No pleas have been entered at this time.

As the crowd gathered outside the U.S. Capitol on 1/6/2021, about 2 p.m., federal prosecutors say Rhodes entered the restricted area of the Capitol grounds and directed his followers to meet him at the Capitol. narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Brian Ulrich conspired with members of the extremist anti-government militia group known as the Oath Keepers to disrupt Congress on Jan. 6. Ulrich has been indicted along with several members of the group. According to the indictment, Ulrich goes by the moniker "Molon Labe" and allegedly participated in conversations on the encrypted messaging service Signal in a group message labeled "DC OP: Jan 6 21." On Dec. 31, Ulrich reportedly wrote the following message on the chat: "The more patriots the merrier 'gonna be wild." Later he allegedly wrote, "Someone can tell me if I'm crazy but I'm planning on having a backpack for regular use and then a separate backpack with my ammo load out with some basics that I can [just] switch too is [sic] s**t truly the fan blades. ..." According to court documents, Ulrich also asked another member on Signal: "Hey we told to bring guns and maybe stage them in VA ...?" On Jan. 4. Ulrich traveled with others to Washington, D.C., from Alabama and Georgia, and stayed at the Mayflower Hotel, court documents say. On the day of the riot, he headed for the U.S. Capitol in a golf cart along with others named in the indictment. He continued on foot and ultimately pushed his way inside through the Rotunda doors, and then, according to court documents, left the same way he came in." (NPR)
source: Charging Documents

narrative: According to an affidavit and criminal complaint, Alan Fischer III marched to the Capitol on 1/6/2022 with members of the Proud Boys. Once there, he moved to the vicinity of the terrace on the west side of the Capitol, where he joined others in pushing against law enforcement at the arched entrance to a passageway into the building. The group of rioters collectively pushed against officers, at times rocking together in a coordinated way, to gain entry to the interior of the building. He remained in this area for a period of more than 45 minutes. Later, according to the court documents, Fischer moved to the west front of the Capitol. Once there, he threw chairs, an orange traffic cone, and a pole towards officers.

narrative: "Wearing a black beanie stitched with a yellow wreath commonly associated with the Proud Boys and a white cowboy hat that referenced the Stop the Steal slogan, Joshua John Portlock allegedly shrugged when officers ordered him out of a tunnel into the U.S. Capitol building. In reply, Portlock allegedly gestured to the crowd surrounding him and said “I can’t with this." He then pleaded with officers to help a fellow rioter having a medical emergency and continued preventing police from closing doors into the Capitol building, according to the statement. Just a half-hour or so before that, FBI agents allege that Portlock pushed open metal barricades and used a large sheet of plywood to drive back a line of police officers in front of the Capitol. Portlock allegedly also joined a crowd of other protesters, chanting “heave-ho” and passing Capitol Police riot shields to other protesters in an attempt to push past officers blocking access to the tunnel into the Capitol. Portlock is a manager with Mitsubishi Motors, according to a LinkedIn page referenced in the FBI statement of facts. Court records show he was arrested on Nov. 3 in Smyrna, Tenn." (NPR)
source: Charging Documents

legal.charges: 18:2384 Seditious conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of official proceeding

narrative: "William Todd Wilson is the third member of the Oath Keepers, an anti-government extremist group, to plead guilty to a charge of seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation into the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Wilson was a county-level leader of the Oath Keepers based in North Carolina, and he conspired with other members of the group to "oppose by force the lawful transfer of presidential power," according to a statement of offense Wilson signed and submitted in federal court as part of his guilty plea. In the days and weeks after the November 2020 presidential election, Wilson exchanged messages with other members of the Oath Keepers about how they believed Joe Biden had stolen the election and, as Oath Keepers leader Stewart Rhodes allegedly put it in one message, "we aren't getting through this without a civil war." On Jan. 5, 2021, Wilson drove from North Carolina to a hotel in Vienna, Va., which is near Washington, D.C., and brought with him an "AR-15-style rifle, a 9-millimeter pistol, approximately 200 rounds of ammunition, body armor, a camouflaged combat uniform, pepper spray, a large walking stick intended for use as a weapon, and a pocketknife," court documents state. Some members of the Oath Keepers allegedly remained at the hotel with a stash of weapons in order to act as a "Quick Reaction Force" that could bring arms into D.C. "in case of worst case scenarios," as Rhodes reportedly wrote in one message. On the day of the riot, Wilson breached the Capitol and helped force open doors to the building's rotunda, according to court documents. Prosecutors allege that at least 14 Oath Keepers breached the Capitol. Wilson left the building and later that evening gathered with Rhodes and other Oath Keepers at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington, D.C. At one point, court documents state, Rhodes called an unidentified person via speakerphone and "repeatedly implore[d] the individual to tell President Trump to call upon groups like the Oath Keepers to forcibly oppose the transfer of power." The person "denied Rhodes's request to speak directly with President Trump," according to court documents, which do not state what relationship that person may have had to Trump. Afterward, members of the group reportedly had dinner at an Olive Garden restaurant and discussed the possibility of taking further actions to fight the transfer of power. In the days after Jan. 6, Wilson deleted messages and information about the alleged plot and threw his cellphone into the Atlantic Ocean." (NPR)
source: Court documents, news articles, governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

narrative: Barry Bennet Ramey, 38, of Plantation, Florida was arrested and charged for his participation in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. A member of the Proud Boys, Ramey came into conflict with U.S. Capitol Police officers on the west side of the building; he was part of the mob pushing against the officers attempting to stop them from climbing the stairwell from the Lower West Terrace to the Upper West Terrace. It is here that Ramey sprayed officers in the eyes with an orange chemical agent, causing disorientation and pain. Though video footage of the incident was captured, the officers were not able to identify the perpetrator of the attack due to the impairment of their vision at the time. Ramey was identified using cell phone location data provided by AT&T--which showed that the phone belonging to Ramey had been using the cell site servicing the U.S. Capitol Building, testimony from the manager of Hilton Arlington Hotel, and identification from a former neighbor. Ramey was then arrested on charges of assaulting police, engaging in physical violence on Capitol grounds, entering a restricted building and civil disorder.
source: Charging Documents, Court Documents, News articles, Government Reports and Release

narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that, in the days after the 2020 election, Rodney Milstreed messaged a friend on Facebook warning that things could get "ugly" in the country, along with a photo of multiple military-style rifles, ammunition and a medical kit. On Nov. 25, 2020, court documents state, he posted on Facebook, "I pray every night. I hope we dont have to hurt anyone. THESE JUDGES BETTER DO THE RIGHT THING." On Jan. 6, 2021, Milstreed allegedly threw a flagpole "javelin-style" at a group of Capitol Police officers guarding the outside of the U.S. Capitol. Later that day, Milstreed can allegedly be seen on video trying to move bike racks that police had set up as a barricade around the building and taking a smoke grenade that was on the ground on the side of the rioters and throwing it toward police. Milstreed then allegedly pulled and shoved a photographer working for The Associated Press, who was covering that day's events. That evening, prosecutors say, he messaged a Facebook friend, "We f***** them federal cops up." Milstreed was arrested on May 24, 2022, in Brighton, Colo." (NPR)
source: Charging Documents

narrative: Joseph Randall Biggs, 37, of Ormond Beach, FL, was charged with Seditious conspiracy; Conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding; Obstruction of an official proceeding and Aiding and abetting; Conspiracy to prevent an officer from discharging any duties; Civil disorder and Aiding and abetting; two counts of Destruction of government property and Aiding and abetting; and two counts of Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers. Biggs was charged along with Dominic Pezzola, Enrique Tarrio, Ethan Nordean, Charles Joseph Donohoe, and Zachary Rehl. The five men, all members of the Proud Boys, encouraged and coordinated other Proud Boys to travel to the Capitol for the January 6 riots, entered the Capitol Building and caused damage while inside, and attempted to cover up their communications regarding their coordination. Their actions were motivated by their rightist: anti-government ideology. Rehl has pled not guilty, the case is currently pending. [Note: Dominic Pezzola was initially charged with Michael J. Greene and William Joseph Pepe (Case ID: 04162021_MJG_PROUDBOYCAP3 and 04162021_WJP_PROUDBOYCAP2, but Pezzola was removed from the case. Pezzola was named 3/7/22 in superseding indictment for the 4PROUDBOYS case, replacing 1:21-cr-52, and named again in the supersceding indictment from 6/6/2022. Charles Donahoe is not included in the supersceding indictment from 6/6/2022, as he pled guilty earlier in the proceedings)
source: Charging documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and releases (DOJ), News articles, Local news articles

narrative: Hatchet M. Speed, born Daniel Abraham Speed, is a Petty Officer First Class in the US Naval Reserves assigned to the Naval Warfare Space Field Activity. He also worked as a defense contractor conducting "advanced analysis for the DOD" and other federal agencies. Speed is charged with his connection to the January 6 riot at the US Capitol. IN conversations with an undercover FBI agent, Speed expressed anti-government, anti-semitic positions including opposition to BLM and anti-fascists, and plans to attack members of the ADL. He praised domestic terrorist Eric Rudolph and the so-called Unabomber, and spoke of browsing Telegram as a source of radicalization. He blamed antifascists for breaching the Capitol. He claimed to have been present at the Capitol with friends who were Proud Boys, and although it does not appear he was a 'patched' member, he at times claimed affiliation with the Proud Boys.
source: Charging Documents, News articles

narrative: On February 14, 2023, Luke Kenna, Michael Brown, Jr., and Brian Tierney were charged by indictment with conspiracy to commit bank robbery. Between 11/14/2022 and 11/27/2022, Kenna, Brown, and Tierney agreed to and planned to commit an armed bank robbery in Johnstown, New York. As part of the planning and conspiracy, Kenna conducted surveillance of the bank and purchased items, including weapons, with thick to commit the robbery. All three men had ties to neo-nazi, white supremacist, and fascist groups on Telegram that frequently shared violent and terroristic content. During the planning, Kenna sent a message to Tierney and Brown stating "Looks like we're getting this paper jew money while it lasts. Just in time to invest into bigger and better things" indicating that a white supremacist, antisemitic, pro-Nazi ideology may have played a role in the intent to conspire to commit the bank robbery. Sentencing is scheduled for 12/15/2023.

legal.charges: 18:1366 Conspiracy to Destroy an Energy Facility;

narrative: Brandon Clint Russell (aka Homunculus & Raccoon), 27, and Sarah Beth Clendaniel (aka Nythra88 & Kali1889), 34, are accused of conspiring to destroy energy facilities in the area of Baltimore, Maryland and Delaware. The substations were located in Norrisville, Reisterstown and Perry Hall, MD, and the final 2 in Baltimore City. They had previously mentioned targeting a substation in Delaware, just beyond the MD border, as well. According to prosecutors, the plans was to damage 5 electrical substations in the Baltimore area with gunfire or through the use of Mylar balloons to cause an electrical short. Then defendants talked about destroying a "ring" around the city, leading to 'complete destruction' of the city through 'cascading failures'--timing the attacks when the electrical grid was already strained (i.e., hot summer or cold winter). The couple were both unknowingly speaking to federal informants in prison during their conspiracy, leading to their arrest. Although the plans began in prison, they continued after Russell was released on parole August 2021, and a focus on the infrastructure attacks began June 2022. The couple met while both were incarcerated in separate facilities--Russell was incarcerated for possessing bomb making materials as part of the Atomwaffen Division, and Clendaniel was imprisoned for robbery. Clendaniel told the informant the she expected to die of kidney disease within months and wanted the attacks to leave a statement. Investigators located a document, described as resembling a manifesto, which includes references to Ted Kaczynski, Anders Brevic and Adolf Hitler. The two reportedly were in contact from 2018 until their arrests in February 2023. Russell is a former Florida National Guard member and a founder of Atomwaffen, and Russell lived with Devon Arthurs, another Atomwaffen member arrested in 2017 for murder, but who had similarly planted to attack US electrical sites and nuclear power plants.
source: Charging document; Court document; Governmental reports and release;

narrative: "The FBI alleges that images from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot show William Hendry Mellors firing a canister of bear spray toward police officers on a staircase leading into the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. “Took a nice beat down from Washington DC police tonight. Some tear gas and a riot baton. Broken ribs and some stitches needed,” Mellors later wrote on Parler as a caption for a close-up photo of what appears to be his own bloody ear, according to an FBI statement of facts. Mellors told FBI agents in April 2022 that he’d joined some “rabid” protesters at the Capitol on Jan. 6, also mentioning that a group of Proud Boys had asked him to “walk some ladies back to their hotel to protect them from Antifa” during the Trump rally in November 2020. He added that the Proud Boys “seemed like nice people.” When FBI agents interviewed Mellors a second time in May, he said he expected to be arrested and confirmed he brought two canisters of bear spray to Washington. He was arrested on July 18, 2022, in Houston" NPR

legal.charges: 18:1366(a) Conspiracy to Destroy Energy Facilities;

narrative: In 2023, in Washington, Matthew Greenwood, 32, pleaded guilty to one count of Conspiracy to Destroy Energy Facilities in U.S. District Court. His co-defendant, Jeremy Crahan, 40, was also involved in the case which is ongoing. Greenwood and Crahan vandalized four power substations and caused thousands of people to lose power on or around Christmas Day, 2022. The two caused thousands of dollars of damage to the substations. They were also planning to cut trees to cause power outages but were caught before the plan was put into action. This scheme aimed to disrupt power and enable them to break into ATMs, businesses, and homes to steal money.

legal.charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assault, Resist, Oppose, Impede, With a Person Engaged in Performance of Official Duties; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:641 Theft of Goverment Property

narrative: On June 13, 2023, a criminal complaint was issued against Richard Zachary Ackerman, 22, of Salem, NH for theft of government property, obstructing law enforcement during civil disorder, resisting a person engaged in official duties, entering and remaining on restricted grounds, and disorderly and disruptive conduct on restricted grounds. On January 6, 2021, Ackerman was part of the crowd that attempted to break a police barricade in the Lower West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol Building. During the riot, Ackerman acquired a U.S. Capitol police helmet, something he termed a "war trophy." Ackerman later attached a New England 131 sticker to the helmet, a sticker referencing the small neo-Nazi group named the Nationalist Social Club 13.
source: Charging documents; court documents; local news articles; governmental reports and release;

legal.charges: 18:241 CONSPIRACY AGAINST RIGHTS; 18:247(c), 18:247(d)(5) DAMAGE TO RELIGIOUS PROPERTY/OBSTRUCTION OF RELIGIOUS BELIEF - damaging religious property;

narrative: "Nathan Weeden, 23, of Houghton, Michigan [was indicted] for conspiring with others and allegedly defacing Temple Jacob – a Jewish synagogue in Hancock, Michigan – with swastikas and symbols associated with The Base, a multi-state, white supremacist group...Weeden, along with other public documents filed in cases against alleged co-conspirators Richard Tobin of New Jersey and Yousef Barasneh of Wisconsin, support the following allegations. According to the indictment, in September 2019, Weeden, Tobin, and Barasneh – all members of The Base, a multi-state, white supremacist organization – allegedly used an encrypted messaging platform to discuss vandalizing property associated with African Americans and Jewish Americans. Weeden and his co-conspirators dubbed their plan, “Operation Kristallnacht,” which in German means “Night of Broken Glass” and is in reference to the events that took place on November 9th and 10th of 1938 in which Nazis murdered Jewish people and burned and destroyed their homes, synagogues, schools, and places of business. The indictment alleges that Weeden carried out this plan on September 21, 2019, when he spray-painted swastikas and symbols associated with The Base on the outside walls of Temple Jacob. Weeden is charged with two counts. The first count is for Conspiracy Against Rights under 18 U.S.C. § 241, a civil rights statute that makes it a crime to conspire to injure, oppress, threaten, or intimidate any person in the exercise of their rights...The second count is for Damage to Religious Property under 18 U.S.C. § 247, also a civil rights statute that makes it a crime to intentionally deface, damage, or destroy religious property because of the race or ethnic characteristics of individuals associated with that religious property. The maximum penalty under this statute is 1 year imprisonment and a $100,000 fine...The grand jury issued its two-count indictment against Nathan Weeden on June 27, 2023. The indictment was unsealed on June 29, 2023, after the defendant was arrested by the FBI. He remains in custody at this time. The court will schedule Weeden’s arraignment, detention hearing, and trial at a later date." (DOJ)
source: Charging document, Governmental report and release; Local News Articles;

narrative: Tyler Dykes, 25, of Bluffton, SC, is charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder, Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, an Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building.
